history.text: Hello, I've read the source page, have you had a chance to do the same?
yeS
Great, I saw this movie last year and enjoyed it.
I like that it is based on true events and shows great character personality.
I thought Big Mike's character was portrayed very well, and Sandra Bullock's acting was terrific.

It was interesting also to see Tim McGraw be an actor
.
I'm not a country fan, so aside from having heard the name before, I had no idea who he was.
I usually don't like when singers become actors or vice versa but he did a pretty good job.

I suppose I'd have to agree since i don't remember taking exception to any of the acting in the movie. Actually, I didn't even know it was based on true events until the credits were about to roll, and only found out just now that it was based also on a book.

Me too. I knew it was based on actual events but didn't know about the book. I may have to look it up. 

I still like to watch the movie when I come across it on tv.
There is so much more to the movie than that little blurb. I feel that doesn't describe so much of the movie.
I think the actors that played the kids were well chosen also. I liked that they didn't chose well-known child actors that were already tied to other movies.

Ah, page 2. Yes I recall this scene now that it's brought to my attention. It seemed to me unrealistic that Sandra Bullock's character would take in Big Mike and put so much trust in a total stranger.
Right? I don't think I could take in a stranger that I had no personal knowledge of and feel safe with my family.
And yeah, definitely much more to this movie, i'm assuming there will be other pages with more content to comment on.
Especially since she had at least one young child in the home.
I liked the scene where there brought him home though and how the actor portraying Mike showed the emotion.
Exactly. I couldn't do it with a young child.
I didn't notice the reviews on the first page, how is it possible that this movie only got a 53/100 metacritic score. I'm certain this won the oscar for best picture.
I was astonished during the scene where her friends act like that. I wouldn't deal with friends like that.
I was surprised by that also. I think Sandra Bullock won but I don't think the movie did.
Oh her friends were total snobs, but that just made her complete acceptance of Mike that much more of a surprise. Typically people and their friends behave similarly.
I would have been so proud if that was my teenage daughter standing up for another person. The way she insisted that he couldn't be thrown out was very adult like.
I start to question now if that actually happened in real life or if that was altered for the movie.
Yea I suppose. I tend not to be friends with people like that.
I think it was close. I know there were interviews with the real daughter where she stated things similarly.

That
'
That's cool. It's always better when they keep it as close as possible to the real thing.
The scene where he says he picked Ole Miss because that's where his family went was so emotional. He finally realized he was part of the family and accepted it.
That gang was nothing but a bunch of bums. They must feel like a bunch of losers knowing how things turned out in the end for michael.
Yeah, cool scene, and great that he was finally allowed entry.
Yep! He made better choices and got a wonderful life instead of ending up in a gang and dead young.
Actually, this movie speaks on a number of inspirational themes. Promoting those in poor living conditions to better themselves, and encouraging the well off to assist those who are less privileged.
Exactly. It shows a different side of the world. In such a way that it's easier to relate to.
Well i see the "finish conversation" button is lit, does that mean it's time for us to wrap up? Truly a terrific movie that deserves a higher rating score.

Yes, it definitely wasn't rated very well. But I feel like it gets better after watching it a few times. 

It was great talking with you!
Likewise, have a nice day.
You too!

uid1response.feedback: This HIT went very smoothly. Would do another.

uid2response.feedback: Thanks! This was a fun task!
